challenges.target_text: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step

challenges.source_text: Umuti utabona umuti wabwo uba urwaye
challenges.target_text: A disease that doesn't find its cure remains a disease.
A pot always has a matching lid.

challenges.source_text: Kajugujugu ka Kamatankoni mu kugukubita yarakuneshaga
challenges.context: Igisakuzo
Igisakuzo

challenges.source_text: Umuti uvura indwara, ariko ubwenge buvuza uburwayi bw'umutima
challenges.target_text: Medicine cures illness, but wisdom cures heartache.

challenges.source_text: I bought a delicious plate of plantains
challenges.context:
Chapter 1: Chapter 1: Arrival in Kigali

I arrived in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, feeling excited!  The city buzzed with activity.  I saw many *amagare* (motorcycles) weaving through the traffic.  I was amazed by the vibrant colours of the *imigongo* (cow dung paintings) displayed in the market.  The friendly faces and warm greetings made me feel immediately welcome. I bought a delicious plate of *matoke* (plantains) from a street vendor. It was the perfect start to my Rwandan adventure!

Chapter 2: Chapter 2: Hiking in Volcanoes National Park

My next stop was Volcanoes National Park, home to the magnificent mountain gorillas.  I embarked on a challenging *inzira* (journey) through lush, green forests.  The air was cool and crisp, filled with the sounds of birdsong. I learned about the importance of *uburinganire* (harmony) in Rwandan culture, which I saw reflected in the peaceful interactions between the park rangers and the tourists.  Reaching the summit and seeing the breathtaking views was incredibly rewarding.  It was truly a magical experience.

challenges.source_text: The serene beauty of the lake took my breath away
challenges.context:
Chapter 3: Chapter 3:  Lake Kivu Relaxation

Finally, I made my way to Lake Kivu.  The serene beauty of the lake took my breath away.  I spent my days swimming in the crystal-clear waters and enjoying the gentle *umuyaga* (breeze).  I took a boat trip to one of the islands on the lake, where I relaxed and took in the magnificent *ibishusho* (scenery).  I watched the sun set over the lake and reflected on my incredible journey through Rwanda. The people, the culture, and the breathtaking landscape left a lasting impression.  It was a trip I’ll never forget!

challenges.source_text: I was already falling in love with Rwanda
challenges.context:
Chapter 1: Chapter 1: Arrival in Kigali

I arrived in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, feeling excited and a little nervous.  The city buzzed with activity –  people hurried past, selling *imbuto* (fruits) and *amata* (milk) from colorful baskets.  The air was warm and filled with the scent of *kawa* (coffee). I checked into my hotel, a beautiful building with stunning views of the rolling hills. I decided to start my adventure by visiting the bustling Kimironko Market, a vibrant place filled with local crafts and delicious street food.  I was amazed by the *ubwiza* (beauty) of the handwoven baskets and the intricate designs on the clothing. The market was full of *abantu* (people), all chatting and laughing.  I bought some *igikoma* (bananas) and a small woven basket as a souvenir. I was already falling in love with Rwanda!

challenges.target_text: Kinyarwanda: Umujyi wa Kigali ugaragaza ubwinshi bw'inyubako n'imiterere y'ubutaka bwa Rwanda | English: Kigali's skyline showcases a blend of modern buildings and Rwanda's hilly landscape.
challenges.context: Describe the image in either Kinyarwanda or English.

challenges.target_text: Kinyarwanda: Ikirunga gifite igicu hejuru cyacyo, kireba ku kiyaga n'ibirunga biri kure | English: A volcano capped with a cloud overlooks a lake and distant hills.
challenges.context: Describe the image in either Kinyarwanda or English.

challenges.source_text: The view of the mountains across the water
challenges.context:
Chapter 2: Chapter 2:  A Hike to Lake Kivu

The next day, I embarked on a hike to the stunning Lake Kivu.  The journey was challenging, but the *ubwiza* (beauty) of the landscape was breathtaking.  I passed fields of lush *ibishyimbo* (beans) and *imyumbati* (cassava), and saw children playing along the way.  They greeted me with a cheerful *Muraho* (hello)!  The *ikirere* (air) was fresh and clean.  Finally, I reached the lake, its waters sparkling under the bright sun.  I spent the afternoon swimming and relaxing on the shore, enjoying the peace and tranquility.  The view of the *imisozi* (mountains) across the water was truly unforgettable.  In the evening, I enjoyed a delicious meal of *isombe* (a type of mashed vegetable dish) and *inyama* (meat) at a local restaurant.

challenges.source_text: Umuti ukomoka kure urusha uwo mu rugo
challenges.target_text: A remedy from afar is better than one from home.
The cure for poverty is work.

{"title": "Exploring Rwanda", "chapters": ["Chapter 1: Arrival in Kigali

I arrived in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, feeling excited and a little nervous.  The city buzzed with activity –  people hurried past, selling *imbuto* (fruits) and *amata* (milk) from colorful baskets.  The air was warm and filled with the scent of *kawa* (coffee). I checked into my hotel, a beautiful building with stunning views of the rolling hills. I decided to start my adventure by visiting the bustling Kimironko Market, a vibrant place filled with local crafts and delicious street food.  I was amazed by the *ubwiza* (beauty) of the handwoven baskets and the intricate designs on the clothing. The market was full of *abantu* (people), all chatting and laughing.  I bought some *igikoma* (bananas) and a small woven basket as a souvenir. I was already falling in love with Rwanda!", "Chapter 2:  A Hike to Lake Kivu

The next day, I embarked on a hike to the stunning Lake Kivu.  The journey was challenging, but the *ubwiza* (beauty) of the landscape was breathtaking.  I passed fields of lush *ibishyimbo* (beans) and *imyumbati* (cassava), and saw children playing along the way.  They greeted me with a cheerful *Muraho* (hello)!  The *ikirere* (air) was fresh and clean.  Finally, I reached the lake, its waters sparkling under the bright sun.  I spent the afternoon swimming and relaxing on the shore, enjoying the peace and tranquility.  The view of the *imisozi* (mountains) across the water was truly unforgettable.  In the evening, I enjoyed a delicious meal of *isombe* (a type of mashed vegetable dish) and *inyama* (meat) at a local restaurant.", "Chapter 3:  Gorilla Trekking and Farewell

My final adventure was gorilla trekking in Volcanoes National Park.  It was an incredible experience, walking through the dense rainforest to encounter these majestic creatures.  Our guide, a friendly *umuntu* (person) named Jean-Paul, led us carefully through the *ishyamba* (forest).  We finally found a family of gorillas, peacefully feeding and resting. Watching them was an unforgettable and humbling experience.  The power and gentleness of these animals was awe-inspiring.  As I prepared to leave Rwanda, I felt a sense of *umunezero* (joy) and gratitude for the incredible experiences I had. I will never forget the *ubuntu* (human kindness) of the Rwandan people and the breathtaking *ubwiza* (beauty) of the country.  Ndi mubwenge (I am clever) to have visited this stunning place."]}
